content.raw: I get that they are all the same size in 3d, but I'm just checking that the compiler will be fine with interchanging them
content.html: I get that they are all the same size in 3d, but I'm just checking that the compiler will be fine with interchanging them

AngularVectorType and LinearVectorType are both defined with a using X = Y declaration. If you have something like

using A = C;
using B = C;

then A and B are considered equivalent symbols. Once compilation has finished, any instance of A or B will be replaced with C.

An unfortunate side-effect of this is it offers less type protection. A user could pass in a Linear Vector quantity into an argument that expects an Angular Vector quantity. I’d be open to tweaking the implementation so that these two types are treated as unique symbols by the compiler, but that’s not something we necessarily need to decide right now. We could change that in the future without significantly impacting the API.

content.raw: The `::FrameData` and `::RelativeFrameData` namespacing was confusing to me, since it looks like these are in the global scope, but I guess it works because of the `using` statements at the top of this file?

content.raw:
Yeah, in general I strongly discourage `using namespace X` anywhere, even inside of translation units, because it can create unresolvable ambiguity with the global namespace. I made an exception here because it’s an integration test for this library, so there isn’t much risk of collisions with symbols from other libraries.

But it’s also confusing for humans to read, so I’m very open to tweaking the style here.
content.html:
Yeah, in general I strongly discourage using namespace X anywhere, even inside of translation units, because it can create unresolvable ambiguity with the global namespace. I made an exception here because it’s an integration test for this library, so there isn’t much risk of collisions with symbols from other libraries.

But it’s also confusing for humans to read, so I’m very open to tweaking the style here.

content.raw:
I noticed that the existing frame semantics tests are all using randomized frame data, so I wanted to add a test based on known inputs. In eec875b78f56 (branch `FrameSemantics_raw_scpeters_test`), I've added a few different reference frames based on different parts of a pivot irrigation system. The test checks that the relative linear velocity at the wheel contact point is near 0, and tests a few other framed quantities.

There is one odd failed expectation. @mxgrey do you mind taking a look at it?

I’ve looked it over, and I see what you mean.

It seems like `B_A`'s linear acceleration makes complete sense. Also, the z-component of `D_A` appears to make sense. But the x-component of `D_A` is very surprising, at least to my intuition.

I’m not spotting anything wrong in the model setup, so there may be something off in how linear acceleration is being computed. But I’m also not spotting anything wrong in the code for that computation. When I get a chance, I’ll try to derive the exact acceleration that would be expected for this dynamic model. That might offer some insight into the test failure.

content.raw:
I've set this scenario up using DART \(in terms of joints rather than generic frames\), and DART's FK gives the exact same surprising result for D’s linear acceleration as `ign-physics` does here.

Granted, I also wrote DART’s FK, but DART has exhaustive unit testing on its FK computations, including tests for velocities and accelerations, so I’m inclined to trust it. Also, DART computes FK using spatial coordinates \(as opposed to the Newton-Euler method we’re using here\), so it seems especially unlikely that two very different formulations would each be flawed in just the right way that they produce the same incorrect result.

I think it’s still worth analytically deriving the acceleration just so we have concrete verification that this is the acceleration that we should expect, but it’s probably not worth looking for bugs in the code unless we find that an analytical solution disagrees with the results.
content.html:

Granted, I also wrote DART’s FK, but DART has exhaustive unit testing on its FK computations, including tests for velocities and accelerations, so I’m inclined to trust it. Also, DART computes FK using spatial coordinates (as opposed to the Newton-Euler method we’re using here), so it seems especially unlikely that two very different formulations would each be flawed in just the right way that they produce the same incorrect result.

I think it’s still worth analytically deriving the acceleration just so we have concrete verification that this is the acceleration that we should expect, but it’s probably not worth looking for bugs in the code unless we find that an analytical solution disagrees with the results.

content.html:

content.raw: I think the main reason eigen is used here is to allow templating on the dimension of the vector types, so you can support types for both 2D and 3D simulation
content.html: I think the main reason eigen is used here is to allow templating on the dimension of the vector types, so you can support types for both 2D and 3D simulation

content.raw:
Not just pose information, but all linear algebraic quantities, like vectors, matrixes, rotations, and transforms would use `Eigen` instead of `ign-math`.

This would allow us to simultaneously support 2D and 3D simulation without doubling all of our development and maintenance effort. At the last ROSCon, I talked with a lot of people who are very interested in using Gazebo for 2D simulation, which is especially useful for testing things like fleet management or swarm control algorithms.

The long-term goal would be to have `ign-math` use `Eigen` for its linear algebra data types. That could easily be achieved with a three step process:

1. Add an optional `Eigen` component to `ign-math` that provides conversion utilities between the two.
2. Make `Eigen` a mandatory dependency of `ign-math` \(or just add the `Eigen` headers to the `ign-math` source code to avoid a new packaging dependency\). Give the existing `ign-math` classes implicit conversions to/from the `Eigen` data types and deprecate the `ign-math` vector, matrix, quaternion, and pose classes.
3. After users have had time to make the switch, consider removing the `ign-math` vector, matrix, quaternion, and pose classes.

This would make `ign-math`'s linear algebra much more powerful, flexible, and performant while also reducing our maintenance efforts. Meanwhile, `ign-math` would continue to provide useful utilities that would build off of the more powerful `Eigen` data structures instead of the less developed custom data structures that we need to maintain ourselves.

There’s more discussion on this topic [here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/929/consider-using-eigen-to-improve-math) and [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/issues/19/consider-using-eigen), so that’s probably where further comments should go.
content.html:
Not just pose information, but all linear algebraic quantities, like vectors, matrixes, rotations, and transforms would use Eigen instead of ign-math.

This would allow us to simultaneously support 2D and 3D simulation without doubling all of our development and maintenance effort. At the last ROSCon, I talked with a lot of people who are very interested in using Gazebo for 2D simulation, which is especially useful for testing things like fleet management or swarm control algorithms.

The long-term goal would be to have ign-math use Eigen for its linear algebra data types. That could easily be achieved with a three step process:

  1. Add an optional Eigen component to ign-math that provides conversion utilities between the two.
  2. Make Eigen a mandatory dependency of ign-math (or just add the Eigen headers to the ign-math source code to avoid a new packaging dependency). Give the existing ign-math classes implicit conversions to/from the Eigen data types and deprecate the ign-math vector, matrix, quaternion, and pose classes.
  3. After users have had time to make the switch, consider removing the ign-math vector, matrix, quaternion, and pose classes.

This would make ign-math's linear algebra much more powerful, flexible, and performant while also reducing our maintenance efforts. Meanwhile, ign-math would continue to provide useful utilities that would build off of the more powerful Eigen data structures instead of the less developed custom data structures that we need to maintain ourselves.

There’s more discussion on this topic here and here, so that’s probably where further comments should go.

content.raw: I added a comment to the ign math issue. We are not using eigen right now. This is a matter of priorities. Eigen is not a priority, and I don't want to get distracted with it.
content.html: I added a comment to the ign math issue. We are not using eigen right now. This is a matter of priorities. Eigen is not a priority, and I don't want to get distracted with it.

content.raw:
If truly generalized support for physics engines is a priority, then Eigen \(or perhaps something functionally equivalent\) should be as well.

If we don’t adopt Eigen or something equivalent now, then our only option will be to redo the entire `ign-physics` design and implementation right now to accommodate `ign-math`'s inherent design limitations. Then in the future if we decide that we do actually want fully generalized support for physics engines, we'll have to throw away everything we did to accommodate `ign-math` and come back to where we are right now and develop from there.

What specifically is the cost of adopting Eigen? It's readily available on all platforms that we support \(and even if it weren't, we can drop its headers into our own repo\). It provides a lot of features that accelerate our ability to develop useful code. It provides users with much richer features. It reduces the amount of maintenance we need to perform. If we make some implicit conversion functions, the transition to using it will be completely painless \(even less painful than the transition from `gazebo::math` to `ignition::math`\). Even if it’s not a priority, it’s exceedingly helpful for accomplishing our priorities, and without any perceivable cost. So I’m very unclear on why it seems to be getting dismissed.
content.html:
If truly generalized support for physics engines is a priority, then Eigen (or perhaps something functionally equivalent) should be as well.

If we don’t adopt Eigen or something equivalent now, then our only option will be to redo the entire ign-physics design and implementation right now to accommodate ign-math's inherent design limitations. Then in the future if we decide that we do actually want fully generalized support for physics engines, we'll have to throw away everything we did to accommodate ign-math and come back to where we are right now and develop from there.

What specifically is the cost of adopting Eigen? It's readily available on all platforms that we support (and even if it weren't, we can drop its headers into our own repo). It provides a lot of features that accelerate our ability to develop useful code. It provides users with much richer features. It reduces the amount of maintenance we need to perform. If we make some implicit conversion functions, the transition to using it will be completely painless (even less painful than the transition from gazebo::math to ignition::math). Even if it’s not a priority, it’s exceedingly helpful for accomplishing our priorities, and without any perceivable cost. So I’m very unclear on why it seems to be getting dismissed.

content.raw: My guess is that the main concern is the external interface and its impact on other ignition projects. It may be ok to keep this approach under the hood for now and make sure the public API to be used by ign-sensors and ign-gazebo uses ignition-math types. That's just a guess
content.html: My guess is that the main concern is the external interface and its impact on other ignition projects. It may be ok to keep this approach under the hood for now and make sure the public API to be used by ign-sensors and ign-gazebo uses ignition-math types. That's just a guess

With implicit conversion operators in the ign-math algebraic types, the other libraries could opaquely receive Eigen objects as if they were ign-math objects. For example, you could have this:

Eigen::Vector3d SomeFunction();

int main()
{
  ignition::math::Vector3d v = SomeFunction();
}

We could even keep those ign-math types around indefinitely if we really wanted to, so no one ever has to move away from ign-math's algebraic types.

Basically, some small tweaks to ign-math would trivially give us complete interoperability between ign-math and Eigen types.

content.raw:
I put a some detail [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/issues/19), but my concernse come down to the following. Just to be clear, since tone and inflection are not present in text, this is not meant to be a rebuke. Rather it’s an insight into how I’d like to handle software development and why.

1. Using Eigen is a major change, one that was not throughoughly discussed with project leaders, which may be just me, or factored into the roadmap. These types of changes will cause us to perpetually chase after the next best feature.
2. “Small tweaks” almost always escalate to major code refactors that affect the entire team. While making a change here or in ign-math may seem small, everyone else may have dedicate time to adopting and adjusting to these small tweaks. This is speculation, but has proven itself to be true very often.
3. While Eigen is definitely better than ign-math in some ways, no one beside developers \(mostly us\) will care. 
4. Different ignition libraries will now use different math libraries, and probably have different public APIs. This makes our libraries look poorly designed. We will also now transform between types, which may \(speculation again\), negatively impact performance.
5. Arguing for Eigen instead of ign-math because we’d have to change code in the future doesn’t carry a lot of weight with me. It is always true that we will have to change and refactor code in the future. A saying that I keep hearing more and more applies here: “Don’t let perfection get in the way of good”, or “Perfection is the enemy of done”.

Since we are now in this situation, we might as well go forward instead of debating the issue. Here is how I’d like to proceed:

1. Limit the amount of changes that downstream users, mostly other ignition library developers, will have to make. This may involve some kind of conversion between types.
2. Limit the use of Eigen in public APIs as much as possible.
3. If there is another major change, which can roughly be anything that effects multiple libraries/people, then make sure the relevant people are informed and have agreed.
content.html:
I put a some detail here, but my concernse come down to the following. Just to be clear, since tone and inflection are not present in text, this is not meant to be a rebuke. Rather it’s an insight into how I’d like to handle software development and why.

  1. Using Eigen is a major change, one that was not throughoughly discussed with project leaders, which may be just me, or factored into the roadmap. These types of changes will cause us to perpetually chase after the next best feature.
  2. “Small tweaks” almost always escalate to major code refactors that affect the entire team. While making a change here or in ign-math may seem small, everyone else may have dedicate time to adopting and adjusting to these small tweaks. This is speculation, but has proven itself to be true very often.
  3. While Eigen is definitely better than ign-math in some ways, no one beside developers (mostly us) will care.
  4. Different ignition libraries will now use different math libraries, and probably have different public APIs. This makes our libraries look poorly designed. We will also now transform between types, which may (speculation again), negatively impact performance.
  5. Arguing for Eigen instead of ign-math because we’d have to change code in the future doesn’t carry a lot of weight with me. It is always true that we will have to change and refactor code in the future. A saying that I keep hearing more and more applies here: “Don’t let perfection get in the way of good”, or “Perfection is the enemy of done”.

Since we are now in this situation, we might as well go forward instead of debating the issue. Here is how I’d like to proceed:

  1. Limit the amount of changes that downstream users, mostly other ignition library developers, will have to make. This may involve some kind of conversion between types.
  2. Limit the use of Eigen in public APIs as much as possible.
  3. If there is another major change, which can roughly be anything that effects multiple libraries/people, then make sure the relevant people are informed and have agreed.

content.raw: This might be nitpicking, but what's the rational for passing the `FrameID` by value in some functions and by const ref in other functions. I understand copying is useful when you want the reference counter to increment, but do we need that here?
content.html: This might be nitpicking, but what's the rational for passing the FrameID by value in some functions and by const ref in other functions. I understand copying is useful when you want the reference counter to increment, but do we need that here?

content.raw:
Great catch, definitely not nitpicking! I think this function was originally written when `FrameID` did nothing but wrap a single integer, at which point copying is just a teensy bit preferable to using a reference. But now that it includes a `std::shared_ptr` as well, reference is definitely preferable.

I've done a pass and changed `FrameID` values to references wherever it seemed relevant: 1290e6f
content.html:

I think this function was originally written when FrameID did nothing but wrap a single integer, at which point copying is just a teensy bit preferable to using a reference. But now that it includes a std::shared_ptr as well, reference is definitely preferable.

I've done a pass and changed FrameID values to references wherever it seemed relevant: 1290e6f

content.raw:
I left fairly minor comments in the code. When initially reading the code, I had some trouble understanding the `FrameData` type because it's name was so similar to `FramedPosition` or `FramedForce`. As it turns out, the latter types are one level of encapsulation higher than `FrameData` and type that encapsulates `FrameData` with a Frame is `RelativeFrameData`. I wish we had a better name for `FrameData`, but I don't have any good suggestions.

Also, I’ve added some more tests to improve coverage of `FrameSpace::ResolveToWorldCoordinates`: [47e5bb9](https://bitbucket.org/azeey/ign-physics/commits/47e5bb970037864161920a211c2f9cf34dbf8cee). Let me know if I should create a PR.
content.html:
I left fairly minor comments in the code. When initially reading the code, I had some trouble understanding the FrameData type because it's name was so similar to FramedPosition or FramedForce. As it turns out, the latter types are one level of encapsulation higher than FrameData and type that encapsulates FrameData with a Frame is RelativeFrameData. I wish we had a better name for FrameData, but I don't have any good suggestions.

Also, I’ve added some more tests to improve coverage of FrameSpace::ResolveToWorldCoordinates: 47e5bb9. Let me know if I should create a PR.

content.raw:
> I had some trouble understanding the `FrameData` type because it's name was so similar to `FramedPosition` or `FramedForce`.

Yeah, I definitely agree it's confusing. `FrameData` looks like it should be similar to `FramedPosition` and `FramedForce`, but really `RelativeFrameData` is closer to them. I didn't want to refer to `RelativeFrameData` as `FramedFrameData`, because that name makes me feel dizzy.

We could consider renaming `FramedPosition` and `FramedForce` to `RelativePosition` and `RelativeForce`, although I’m not totally sure if “relative” is the most appropriate word to use for those types of quantities.

I’m definitely open to changing the names of these things; it’s just a bit of a head-scratcher to come up with names that are expressive and consistent.

Edit: If we decide to switch `Framed` to `Relative`, we could also rename `FramedQuantity` to `RelativeQuantity`. Again, I'm not 100% sure that `Relative` is the best adjective to use here, but if others think it’s acceptable and preferable, we could make that change.
content.html:

Yeah, I definitely agree it's confusing. FrameData looks like it should be similar to FramedPosition and FramedForce, but really RelativeFrameData is closer to them. I didn't want to refer to RelativeFrameData as FramedFrameData, because that name makes me feel dizzy.

We could consider renaming FramedPosition and FramedForce to RelativePosition and RelativeForce, although I’m not totally sure if “relative” is the most appropriate word to use for those types of quantities.

I’m definitely open to changing the names of these things; it’s just a bit of a head-scratcher to come up with names that are expressive and consistent.

Edit: If we decide to switch Framed to Relative, we could also rename FramedQuantity to RelativeQuantity. Again, I'm not 100% sure that Relative is the best adjective to use here, but if others think it’s acceptable and preferable, we could make that change.

content.raw: Since `FrameData` consists of Pose, Velocity, and Acceleration, should we consider calling it `KinematicData` or `KinematicState`? Then `FramedKinematicData` or `FramedKinematicState` could be used?
content.html: Since FrameData consists of Pose, Velocity, and Acceleration, should we consider calling it KinematicData or KinematicState? Then FramedKinematicData or FramedKinematicState could be used?

content.raw: The [comment](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/26/feature-system-part-2-frame-semantics/diff#Linclude/ignition/physics/FrameData.hhT63) already states "The FrameData struct fully describes the kinematic state of a Frame with "Dim" dimensions and "Scalar" precision."  So `KinematicState` seems appropriate if it doesn’t create confusion for other reasons I’m not aware of.
content.html: The comment already states "The FrameData struct fully describes the kinematic state of a Frame with "Dim" dimensions and "Scalar" precision." So KinematicState seems appropriate if it doesn’t create confusion for other reasons I’m not aware of.

content.raw: ok, @mxgrey how do you feel about `FrameData` -> `KinematicState` and `RelativeFrameData` -> `FramedKinematicState`?
content.html: ok, @mxgrey how do you feel about FrameData -> KinematicState and RelativeFrameData -> FramedKinematicState?

content.raw:
I think `KinematicState` is more specific and precise than `FrameData`, but maybe not precise enough because people might think of multi body kinematics, which is a bit different and more complex.

Maybe `CartesianState` or `CartesianKinematicState` is more precise?
content.html:
I think KinematicState is more specific and precise than FrameData, but maybe not precise enough because people might think of multi body kinematics, which is a bit different and more complex.

Maybe CartesianState or CartesianKinematicState is more precise?

content.raw:
Does anyone have thoughts on keeping `FrameData` as-is and finding a term other than `Framed` to put in front of the other types? So instead of `FramedVelocity`, we would have `XxxxVelocity` where we need to figure out what `Xxxx` should be \(e.g. `RelativeVelocity`\)?

Is that still on the table, or are there objections to it?
content.html:
Does anyone have thoughts on keeping FrameData as-is and finding a term other than Framed to put in front of the other types? So instead of FramedVelocity, we would have XxxxVelocity where we need to figure out what Xxxx should be (e.g. RelativeVelocity)?

Is that still on the table, or are there objections to it?

content.raw: I think I marginally like `Framed` better than `Relative`, but consistency is better, so I would favor replacing all the `Framed` prefixes with `Relative`. If @azeey agrees, I'll go ahead and make make that change so we can move forward
content.html: I think I marginally like Framed better than Relative, but consistency is better, so I would favor replacing all the Framed prefixes with Relative. If @azeey agrees, I'll go ahead and make make that change so we can move forward

content.raw: I am good with `Relative`.
content.html: I am good with Relative.

content.raw: Similar to the [other comment](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/26/feature-system-part-2-frame-semantics/activity#comment-73204172) about `FrameIDs`, would it be better to create a member variable of type `FrameID` in the `Frame` constructor and return a const ref to it when `GetFrameID` is called?
content.html: Similar to the other comment about FrameIDs, would it be better to create a member variable of type FrameID in the Frame constructor and return a const ref to it when GetFrameID is called?

content.raw:
In my opinion, not in this case.

An important aspect of the PImpl\+ECS design is that absolutely nothing in the inheritance structure contains any member data except for the bottom-most base `Entity<P, F>` class.

It's plausible that we might get some marginal performance improvement if we have this class store a `FrameID` object that gets initialized during construction and then returned by reference here. However, it’s also plausible that this would result in a marginal hit to performance, because it means copying and moving are more expensive.

Worse, doing this would make copying and moving much more complicated. Right now, since every "Feature API" class contains no member data, we can have our highest-level copy and move operations do nothing but `static_cast<Entity<P, F>&>(*this) = other;` and `static_cast<Entity<P, F>&(*this) = std::move(other)`. This is helpful because otherwise copy and move operations would have to traverse the entire inheritance structure, calling the copy/move operations of all member objects recursively. Since we're using lots of virtual inheritance, this means that many data members would be getting redundantly copied/moved again and again. By taking advantage of the fact that absolutely all data is stored solely in `Entity<P, F>`, we can write extremely efficient copies and moves.

And then factoring in things like Return Value Optimization as well as the fact that this data structure is extremely light weight, I don’t think it’s worth tainting the inheritance structure by adding member data for this case alone.
content.html:
In my opinion, not in this case.

An important aspect of the PImpl+ECS design is that absolutely nothing in the inheritance structure contains any member data except for the bottom-most base Entity<P, F> class.

It's plausible that we might get some marginal performance improvement if we have this class store a FrameID object that gets initialized during construction and then returned by reference here. However, it’s also plausible that this would result in a marginal hit to performance, because it means copying and moving are more expensive.

Worse, doing this would make copying and moving much more complicated. Right now, since every "Feature API" class contains no member data, we can have our highest-level copy and move operations do nothing but static_cast<Entity<P, F>&>(*this) = other; and static_cast<Entity<P, F>&(*this) = std::move(other). This is helpful because otherwise copy and move operations would have to traverse the entire inheritance structure, calling the copy/move operations of all member objects recursively. Since we're using lots of virtual inheritance, this means that many data members would be getting redundantly copied/moved again and again. By taking advantage of the fact that absolutely all data is stored solely in Entity<P, F>, we can write extremely efficient copies and moves.

And then factoring in things like Return Value Optimization as well as the fact that this data structure is extremely light weight, I don’t think it’s worth tainting the inheritance structure by adding member data for this case alone.

content.raw: Makes sense. Thanks for the explanation.
content.html: Makes sense. Thanks for the explanation.
